subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Hyundai Engineering (000720 KS) receives KRW 3.2tln of orders from Saudi Aramco
content:
AUSTRALIA

Bell Financial Group (BFG AT) - Co. H1 EPS rose 35% Y/Y to around AUD 0.05/Shr and revenue rose 21% Y/Y to around AUD 120mln. (Newswires)

Evolution Mining (EVN AT) - Co. Q4 gold output 194.9K ounces vs. Prev. 202.3K ounces Y/Y. (Newswires)

Ramelius Resources (RMS AT) - Co. Q4 gold output 47.3k ounces vs. Prev. 58.3k ounces Y/Y. (Newswires)

Ruralco (RHL AT) - Delta Agribusiness is examining various assets that may need be divested for Landmark to receive approval to acquire Ruralco. (Newswires)

Stockland (SGP AT) - Co. is to sell its Tooronga shopping centre for AUD 63mln. (AFR)

Financials - S&P revised ANZ, CBA, NAB and Westpac outlooks to Stable from Negative. (Newswires)

Other News - RBA watcher McCrann suggested that plenty of stimulus provides the RBA time to assess and that there is a good reason there will not be another rate cut or more government handouts any time soon. (Herald Sun)

 

JAPAN

Chiba Bank (8331 JT) - Co. is considering a business alliance with Yokohama Bank (8332 JT). (Newswires)

Japan Tobacco (2914 JT) - Co. announces top-line results from its Phase 3 clinical study of Riona for adult patients with iron deficiency anaemia in which the results met the primary endpoint. (Newswires)

Rakuten (4755 JT) - Co. is said to plan eliminating minimum trading fees for US equities after a similar move by Monex. (Newswires)

Suruga Bank (8358 JT) - Co. is said to resolve founding family issue by September. (Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Engineering (000720 KS) - Co. receives KRW 3.2tln of orders from Saudi Aramco. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) - Co. and SK Hynix (000660 KS) are to reduce NAND output as early this month. (Newswires)

Other News South Korea President Moon will meet with the heads of 30 large industrial companies today regarding Japanese export curbs. (Newswires)

South Korea Ambassador has asked Japan to withdraw its trade restrictions at the WTO and stated that they will disrupt global value chains for electronic products as well as affect companies worldwide, while the Ambassador added that WTO rules do not allow Japan to impose export controls due to the damage of trust between the two countries although the Japanese envoy said its measures are allowed under WTO rules. (Newswires)

China has asked banks to limit loans for property
BP is beginning to evacuate staff and shutting in production at 4 US Gulf of Mexico platforms

US State Department urges Turkish authorities to halt drilling operations off the Cyprus coast
BHP is removing workers from 2 US Gulf of Mexico offshore platforms as a precaution ahead of the storm
UK Brexit Secretary Barclay reportedly warned the EU that a no-deal Brexit will hurt Ireland more than Britain

Turkey President Erdogan says former Central Bank Governor Centinkaya did not communicate with markets well
Brazil House Speaker Maia says still working towards pension reform vote on Tuesday night
Shell evacuates non-essential employees from eastern Gulf operations after NHC recently stated there was a 70% chance of a cyclone forming in Northern Gulf of Mexico over next 48 hours
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin spoke with China Vice Premier Liu He today to continue negotiations aimed at resolving the outstanding trade disputes between the US and China, while talks will continue "as appropriate" according to a US official and an aide for President Trump also suggested that Lighthizer and Mnuchin may travel to China 'soon'. (Twitter/NYT)

NEC Director Kudlow said the US-China call this week will be followed by an in-person meeting and that China is expected to move on agriculture purchases even as trade talks are moving forward, while he also commented that the relaxed US government restrictions on Huawei are to be in place for a limited time period and will assist the Co. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Minister strongly opposes US arms sales to Taiwan and called on the US to withdraw these arm sales to Taiwan. In related news, China Global Times Editor questioned who will be the first to flinch out of US, Taiwan and Beijing in a showdown if the US arms sale to Taiwan crosses the line of Beijing and Beijing announces to destroy the weapons if they are placed on the island, while the editor also warned “Don’t play with fire". (Newswires/Twitter)

South Korea Ambassador has asked Japan to withdraw its trade restrictions at the WTO and stated that they will disrupt global value chains for electronic products as well as affect companies worldwide, while the Ambassador added that WTO rules do not allow Japan to impose export controls due to the damage of trust between the two countries although the Japanese envoy said its measures are allowed under WTO rules. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that India has long had a field day putting tariffs on American products and that it is no longer acceptable. (Twitter)

 

UK/EU

UK lawmakers voted in favour of a plan which might hinder government from suspending Parliament if it pursues a no deal Brexit as MPs approved Amendment 15 by 294 to 293 which requires fortnightly reports to be made after the conference recess until a Northern Irish Executive is formed, or until the December recess. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department said the meeting between US Commerce Secretary Ross and UK International Trade Secretary Fox has been cancelled. (Sky News)

Germany and France reportedly agreed some time ago to support BoE Governor Carney to lead the IMF, although the French Finance Minister was said to have refuted this claim. (FAZ)

 

FX

Mexico Finance Minister Urzua resigned as he felt forced to quit due to the conflicts of interests he has seen in government and how administration decisions were made without sufficient backing, while Deputy Finance Minister Herrera was later announced as the new Finance Minister. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

API Weekly Crude Inventories -8.129mln vs. Exp. -3.1mln (Prev. -5.0mln). (Newswires)

EIA Short Term Energy Outlook cut 2019 world oil demand growth view by 150k/day to 1.07mln BPD and 2020 world oil demand growth was cut by 20k BPD to 1.40mln BPD. Furthermore, EIA raised 2019 US output forecast to 12.36mln BPD (Prev. 12.62mln BPD) but forecasts US crude output to rise by 900k BPD in 2020 to 13.26mln BPD (Prev. forecast to rise 940k BPD). (Newswires)

Russian oil output fell 3% for July 1st-8th vs. June average with output at 10.79mln BPD vs. Prev. 11.15mln BPD, while Rosneft's oil output for the same period was lower by 11%, according to industry sources. In other news, Russia have undertaken a complaint at the WTO challenging US anti-dumping measures on the import of hot-rolled steel from Russia. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iraq PM Abdul-Mahdi said he has concerns over the potential disruption of navigation of oil exports through the Strait of Hormuz and that the government is looking at contingency plans to find an alternative route for oil exports if the Hormuz is disrupted. In related news, a top US General said the US is seeking to enlist allies in an effort to safeguard shipping in Strait of Hormuz and Bab el-Mandeb. (Newswires)

Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif tweeted that US National Security Advisor Bolton and Israel PM Netanyahu killed the Paris agreement in 2005 by insisting on zero enrichment and Iran then increased enrichment 100-fold by 2012 while he added that now US President Trump has been lured into killing the JCPOA with the same delusion. Elsewhere, there were also reports that the US is still considering sanctions on Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif.

Israel PM Netanyahu said Iran should note that it is within range of Israeli warplanes and cited recent Iranian threats to destroy Israel. (Newswires)

EU is reportedly considering cutting European Investment Bank funding to Turkey and the suspension of aviation talks, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Harker (Non-Voter, Hawk) sees no reason to move interest rates at this point but noted that trade has created some uncertainties and that he would entertain rate cuts if he believed the economy was ‘weakening substantially’. (WSJ)

Fed's Bostic (Non-Voter, Dove) said the Fed is debating the merits and risks of running a hot labour market, while he added there are risks of the labour market becoming too tight. (Newswires)

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell declined to predict when Congress will approve the new US debt limit but sees no chance of a default. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow said the Fed has the room to reverse the December rate hike based on price signals and suggested to look at price indicators not job indicators in reference to the upcoming FOMC decision. Furthermore, Kudlow said the Fed should be aiming for price level stability and a steady USD not focusing on jobs data, while he separately commented that US and EU are in talks to move forward on a trade agreement. (Newswires/WSJ) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) shares were supported on positive broker comments, including from Evercore ISI and Morgan Stanley. Boeing (BA) was under pressure after disappointing orders data, however did later see some upside after on the news that Qatar was planning to buy “large numbers” of Boeing commercial jets, although when the disappointing details of this transaction were revealed (just five 777S jets) the move was reversed. Netflix (NFLX) was buoyant after positive comments from Cowen. Merck (MRK) moved higher up after a judge struck down a Trump administration bill that would force drug makers to include the cost of medications in TV adverts and on further Keytruda progression with the FDA. Macy’s Inc (M) jumped higher on takeover chatter. Hotel names, including Marriot (MAR) and Hilton (HLT), were under pressure after JPM said it was increasingly cautious on US lodging firms. DaVita Inc (DVA) and Fresenius Medical Care (FMS) fell on a Politico report that the Trump administration is planning to encourage more kidney transplants and at-home dialysis. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) shares moved higher after Instinet raised its PT for the firm to USD 37. Square (SQ) shares jumped higher on an upgrade at Raymond James, who said they see no negative catalysts on the horizon. Notable stocks under pressure after broker downgrades: 3M (MMM) down on RBC Capital downgrade, QEP Resources (QEP) down on Oppenheimer downgrade. S&P 500 0.1% at 2980, NASDAQ-100 0.5% at 7827, Dow Jones -0.1% at 26785.

Ranges were thin as traders wait on cues from Fed Chair Powell, who is due to testify to lawmakers on Wednesday. A 'double' rate cut of 50bps at the July FOMC has been priced out, and the question, analysts say is what is the Fed's conviction of the trajectory of rates through to the end of the year; currently around 2.5 rate hikes are priced in by money markets by the end of 2019; the median Fed 'dot' sees rates unchanged for the rest of the year. Ahead of the Fedspeak, the US Treasury sold 3-year notes at 1.857%, the lowest high yield since November 2017; the sale stopped through the screens by 0.1bps. Cover was soft, the lowest since March 2019. The breakdown, meanwhile, saw indirect participation pare back (48.5% vs 56.6% prior), with direct participation rising to 17.9% from 13.4%, and dealers taking from 30.0% prior. US T-note futures (U9) settled 6+ ticks lower at 127-09+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 9th July 2019: Traders await Powell testimony on Wednesday
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up/flat, Treasuries down, dollar up, crude up/flat.
  • REAR VIEW: Lighthizer, Mnuchin spoke to Liu, may travel to China 'soon'; US & EU in talks to move forward on a trade agreement; NEC Director Kudlow repeats familiar Fed criticism; US still mulling sanctions on Iran foreign minister Zarif.
  • COMING UP: Data; Japanese Corporate Goods, Chinese CPI & Money Supply, UK GDP (Estimate) & Services, Events; BoC Rate Decision, FOMC Minutes & European Economic Forecasts (Interim Report), Speakers; Fed’s Powell, George & Bullard, BoC’s Poloz & Wilkins and BoE’s Tenreyro, Auctions; German 2029 & US 10yr.

* FED: Fed Chair Powell stayed away from policy related comments in his remarks on Tuesday, sticking to the theme of stress-testing.  Arch-dove Bullard (voter) was due to give comments on Monday, however, nothing hit the wires; traders were looking for more detail on his views that a 50bps insurance rate cut might be ‘excessive’. Meanwhile, Fed's Bostic (non-voter) said Fed is debating the merits and risks of running a hot labour market; adds there are risks of the labour market becoming too tight.

* POWELL TESTIMONY (WED)/FED MINUTES PREVIEW (WED): Minutes to the FOMC’s June meeting might be overshadowed by the timelier dual-testimonies that Fed Chair Powell will deliver to lawmakers on Wednesday and Thursday. However, traders will look to both Powell’s remarks and the meeting minutes to gauge not only the prospects of a 25bps/50bps rate cut at the July meeting, but also the trajectory of the Fed’s rate path through to the end of the year. The markets have priced out the prospects of the ‘double’ rate cut after a solid employment situation report last week; however, other risks, especially prices and global growth, could still give the FOMC optionality to loosen policy. The minutes will be released at 1900 BST/1400 EDT on 10th July 2019. To download the report, please click here.

* NEC DIRECTOR KUDLOW: Repeated his familiar criticism that growth and low unemployment do not cause inflation, and as such, the FOMC has scope to ‘take back’ its 25bps December rate hike.

* TRADE: Overnight the US Commerce Department said it would slap duties on Chinese and Mexican fabricated steel imports, after it judged that both nations are unfairly subsidising the product; the decision is prelim, and a final decision could come in November. Deutsche Bank noted that imports of fabricated structural steel from China and Mexico in 2018 were valued at an estimated USD 897.5mln and USD 622.4mln respectively, and in the greater scheme of things, it is relatively small; however, the optics are key, given the tense stage of trade negotiations between the US and China, the bank said. Elsewhere, Russia has undertaken a complaint at the WTO challenging US anti-dumping measures on the import of hot-rolled steel from Russia, according to a WTO filing.

* CHINA: China’s Vice Foreign Minister Le Yucheng warned of ‘disastrous consequences’ if the US treats China as an enemy and criticized Washington over reports some Chinese-American scientists were treated unfairly in the US. Later, USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Sec Mnuchin spoke with China Vice Premier Liu He today to "continue negotiations aimed at resolving the outstanding trade disputes between the US and China," US official says, adding talks will continue "as appropriate". Also, the US announced it has approved USD 2.2bln of arms sales to Taiwan, in a move likely to irritate China; one Chinese reporter stated that if the US sold arms to Taiwan, Beijing would task the PLA (China army) would destroy the weapons, adding that in that scenario, geopolitical tensions would be escalated.

* GEOPOLITICAL: A US official said it is still mulling sanctions on Iran foreign minister Zarif; Zarif on Twitter said US National Security Advisor Bolton and Israel PM Netanyahu killed the Paris agreement in 2005 by insisting on zero enrichment, Iran then increased enrichment 100 fold by 2012, and Zarif said now, US President Trump has been lured into killing the JCPOA with the same delusion. Later, reports said that several secret meetings between US and Iranian officials took place in Iraq last week, according to I24News, citing Iranian sources. With regards to Turkey, EU is reportedly considering cutting European Investment Bank funding to Turkey and the suspension of aviation talks, according to sources.

* BOC PREVIEW: The BOC is expected to keep rates unchanged at 1.75%. There will be attention on whether the Bank chooses to tweak forward guidance and introduce an easing bias; however, most analysts are of the view that the BOC will avoid doing this, and reiterate the current stance remains appropriate. The MPR will likely see near-term growth forecasts upgraded, though will likely revise down its view of global growth; the output gap and inflation estimates could be nudged higher. Rate decision and MPR due for release at 1500 BST/1000 EDT, and the post-meeting press conference with Governor Poloz and Deputy Governor Wilkins will begin at 1615 BST/1115 EDT. To download the report, please click here.

* BREXIT: House Speaker Bercow did not add an amendment proposed by Dominic Grieve, which aimed to prevent the government from proroguing Parliament; it would have required the House to be in session on 4th September and 9th October, and then every fortnight through to 18th December, in an effort to prevent the government from suspending parliament to force through a no-deal Brexit. Later, Grieve tabled another amendment which lawmakers voted in favour of, which requires Parliament to provide fortnightly reports to be made after the conference recess until a Northern Irish Executive is formed, or until the December recess; analysts said that this technically does not rule out prorogation, and accordingly, prorogation could still be a strategy used by a future government. On the other side of the House, UK Jeremy Corbyn has written to Labour members saying the new Prime Minister should "put their deal, or no deal, back to the people in a public vote" saying Labour would campaign for remain against "no deal or a Tory deal that does not protect the economy and jobs".  Meanwhile, BRC retail sales data overnight printed -1.6% Y/Y, in another sign that the UK economy slowed in Q2.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 6+ TICKS LOWER AT 127-09+: Ranges were thin as traders wait on cues from Fed Chair Powell, who is due to testify to lawmakers on Wednesday. A 'double' rate cut of 50bps at the July FOMC has been priced out, and the question, analysts say is what is the Fed's conviction of the trajectory of rates through to the end of the year; currently around 2.5 rate hikes are priced in by money markets by the end of 2019; the median Fed 'dot' sees rates unchanged for the rest of the year. Ahead of the Fedspeak, the US Treasury sold 3-year notes at 1.857%, the lowest high yield since November 2017; the sale stopped through the screens by 0.1bps. Cover was soft, the lowest since March 2019. The breakdown, meanwhile, saw indirect participation pare back (48.5% vs 56.6% prior), with direct participation rising to 17.9% from 13.4%, and dealers taking from 30.0% prior.

* WTI (Q9) SETTLES USD 0.17 HIGHER AT USD 57.83; BRENT (U9) SETTLES USD 0.05 HIGHER AT USD 64.16. The energy complex got off on the front foot on Tuesday, but gains were pared back as we approached settlement, leaving crude mixed, with participants likely keeping their powder dry ahead of the energy inventories/heavy slate of Fedspeak, where crude traders will be keeping an ear out for commentary on global growth. There was not too much in the way of substantial developments in the oil market on Tuesday, with analysts noting the same narratives of geopolitical risk being price supportive and global growth concerns providing headwinds. However, it was reported that Russia’s oil output fell to 10.79mln BPD in the beginning of July, down from 11.15mln BPD in June; although a promising sign for OPEC+ production cut compliance, it’s unlikely that this much of a cut was voluntary given the production problems in Russia, with a growing divide between the state-owned pipeline monopoly Transneft and the country’s largest producer Rosneft due to the handling of the contaminated oil which has plagued supply out of the region. After the bell the API will report its US energy inventory figures, where analysts look for headline crude stocks to draw by 3.1mln (Cushing expected to draw by 420k); distillates are seen building 0.7mln, and gasoline is seen drawing 1.3mln.

* EIA STEO: The agency cuts 2019 world oil demand growth view by 150k/day to 1.07mln BPD; 2020 world oil demand growth cut by 20k BPD to 1.40mln BPD. The IEA monthly report and the OPEC MOMR are to be released later in the week. EIA lowered its US output forecast for 2019 to 12.36mln BPD (prev. 12.62mln BPD) and forecasts US crude output to rise by 900k BPD in 2020, to 13.26mln BPD (prev. forecast to rise 940k BPD).

* S&P 500 0.1% at 2980, NASDAQ-100 0.5% at 7827, Dow Jones -0.1% at 26785, Sectors; Consumer Discretionary 0.3%, Consumer Staples -0.6%, Energy 0.1%, Financials 0.3%, Health Care 0.1%, Industrials -0.2%, Information Technology 0.3%, Materials -1%, Telecommunication Services  0.3%, Utilities  0.1%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) shares were supported on positive broker comments, including from Evercore ISI and Morgan Stanley. Boeing (BA) was under pressure after disappointing orders data, however did later see some upside after on the news that Qatar was planning to buy “large numbers” of Boeing commercial jets, although when the disappointing details of this transaction were revealed (just five 777S jets) the move was reversed. Netflix (NFLX) was buoyant after positive comments from Cowen. Merck (MRK) moved higher up after a judge struck down a Trump administration bill that would force drug makers to include the cost of medications in TV adverts and on further Keytruda progression with the FDA. Macy’s Inc (M) jumped higher on takeover chatter. Hotel names, including Marriot (MAR) and Hilton (HLT), were under pressure after JPM said it was increasingly cautious on US lodging firms. DaVita Inc (DVA) and Fresenius Medical Care (FMS) fell on a Politico report that the Trump administration is planning to encourage more kidney transplants and at-home dialysis. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) shares moved higher after Instinet raised its PT for the firm to USD 37. Square (SQ) shares jumped higher on an upgrade at Raymond James, who said they see no negative catalysts on the horizon. Notable stocks under pressure after broker downgrades: 3M (MMM) down on RBC Capital downgrade, QEP Resources (QEP) down on Oppenheimer downgrade.

* FX WRAP: USD has been treading water (slightly up) ahead of the highly anticipated testimony on Wednesday by Fed Chair Powell, which traders are expecting will be pivotal in understanding the trajectory of the Federal Funds Rate target. EUR is consolidating around 1.12, though a raft of analyst notes have been calling the currency lower as dovish ECB chatter increases, the prospect of a dovish ECB president, as well as pricing out of a ‘double’ rate cut at the Fed’s July meeting; additionally, some now expect the ECB to ease as early as the July meeting, with some desks looking for a rate cut of 20bps. GBP was weaker as the House Speaker did not select an amendment that would put a hurdle in the way of a no-deal Brexit, while BRC data continues to show the challenges the UK economy faces in Q2. AUD was lower, partially on a stronger dollar, partially on weaker NAB confidence data, which had the net impact of pushing AUD through its 50dma (around 0.6950) to the downside. CAD was weaker ahead of tomorrow’s BOC meeting, after housing data came in on the soft side. MXN was hit after news its finance minister has resigned, due to conflicts of interests he has seen in government, and how administration decisions were made without sufficient backing. Mexico President Obrador announced Deputy Finance Minister Herrera as the new Finance Minister. BRL maintains a small edge over the buck after pension reform momentum increases.

* EUR: USD strength and dovish ECB chatter have placed the 1.12 handle under threat, as traders expect rate cuts/QE2/both in the months ahead. On Monday, Coeure said accommodation was needed “more than ever,” which follows dovish comments last week from hawk Knott, as well as the prospect of a dovish ECB President replacing Draghi. SocGen’s analysts see a rate cut as soon as July, and ask why the volume is suddenly being turned up, if the intention is not to move until September? The bank says that a 20bps cut in the deposit rate, or a statement of an intention to resume bond purchases after the summer are within the realm of possibilities. The bank says it makes it hard not to stay with current tactics and sell the single currency on rallies.

* BRL: With pension reform now having passed its first hurdle, clearing a special committee, it has set up a vote in the Lower House before Congress goes into recess on 18th July. Julius Baer’s analysts explain that pension reform is the most important factor in the effort to structurally decrease Brazil’s neutral interest rate, and boost growth, and the BCB has indicated that it needs concrete signs that the pension reform is moving forward before it starts cutting interest rates to stimulate the economy (the market currently prices around 100bps of Selic rate cuts by year-end). The bill will now be sent to the Lower House for two separate votes before moving to the Senate for final approval. The bill is expected to pass through Congress; Globo News recently reported that 318 deputies in the Lower House are in favour of the proposed pension reform, 10 above the minimum required to reach a Congressional majority. Analysts say a successful outcome could push USDBRL down to February levels around 3.63; however, as we have noted already this week, EMFX will take immediate cues from Fed Chair Powell in is testimonies this week.

* MXN: Data showed inflationary pressures cooling in June, falling from 4.3% Y/Y to 3.9%, with lower energy prices the driving force. Analysts see further deceleration in the next month’s data, and this could open the door for Banxico rate cuts ahead. In other news, the peso faced downside pressure against the buck on news that the Mexican finance minister was to resign, which sent the MXN back above 19.00; technicians say, however, that if we can strengthen to the near 10-week lows we have visited earlier, a breach of 18.90 could open the door to the April low around 18.7480.

* CNY: Desks have noted now that the PBOC has stayed away from open market operations for 12 straight days, citing the abundant liquidity conditions in the banking system. However, the market is still expecting rate cuts, perhaps as soon as this month.

The bill will now be sent to the Lower House for two separate votes before moving to the Senate for final approval. The bill is expected to pass through Congress; Globo News recently reported that 318 deputies in the Lower House are in favour of the proposed pension reform, 10 above the minimum required to reach a Congressional majority. Analysts say a successful outcome could push USDBRL down to February levels around 3.63; however, as we have noted already this week, EMFX will take immediate cues from Fed Chair Powell in is testimonies this week.

* MXN: Data showed inflationary pressures cooling in June, falling from 4.3% Y/Y to 3.9%, with lower energy prices the driving force. Analysts see further deceleration in the next month’s data, and this could open the door for Banxico rate cuts ahead. In other news, the peso faced downside pressure against the buck on news that the Mexican finance minister was to resign, which sent the MXN back above 19.00; technicians say, however, that if we can strengthen to the near 10-week lows we have visited earlier, a breach of 18.90 could open the door to the April low around 18.7480.

* CNY: Desks have noted now that the PBOC has stayed away from open market operations for 12 straight days, citing the abundant liquidity conditions in the banking system. However, the market is still expecting rate cuts, perhaps as soon as this month.

subject: UK lawmakers have voted in favour of a plan which might hinder government from suspending Parliament if it pursues a no deal Brexit
content:
• MPs approve Amendment 15 by 294 to 293.
  • This amendment requires fortnightly reports to be made after the conference recess until a Northern Irish Executive is formed, or until the December recess. 
  • The Amendment author Grieve himself thinks that this amendment will get beefed up in the Lords to make it more effective, Guardian reports
  • Amendment stated “(1A) The secretary of state shall make a further report under subsection 1 on or before 9 October 2019 at least every fourteen calendar days thereafter until either an Executive is formed or until 18 December 2019, whichever is the sooner.”
  • Explanatory notes say this amendment would require fortnightly reports to be made after the conference recess until an executive was formed, or until the December recess.
reaction_details: There was a delayed price reaction, but GBP eventually moved from 1.2462 to 1.2474, further backing away from YTD lows (which some screens suggested we hit again today), as pro-EU lawmakers try and put hurdles in the way of any future PM who wishes to prorogue parliament to push through a no deal exit
analysis_details: NOTE: This does not rule out prorogation, it only requires fortnightly updates. Accordingly, prorogation could still be a strategy used by a future government.

subject: WTI (Q9) settles USD 0.17 higher at USD 57.83; Brent (U9) settles USD 0.05 higher at USD 64.16
analysis_details: The energy complex got off on the front foot on Tuesday, but gains were pared back as we approached settlement, leaving crude mixed, with participants likely keeping their powder dry ahead of the energy inventories/heavy slate of Fedspeak, where crude traders will be keeping an ear out for commentary on global growth. There was not too much in the way of substantial developments in the oil market on Tuesday, with analysts noting the same narratives of geopolitical risk being price supportive and global growth concerns providing headwinds. However, it was reported that Russia’s oil output fell to 10.79mln BPD in the beginning of July, down from 11.15mln BPD in June; although a promising sign for OPEC+ production cut compliance, it’s unlikely that this much of a cut was voluntary given the production problems in Russia, with a growing divide between the state-owned pipeline monopoly Transneft and the country’s largest producer Rosneft due to the handling of the contaminated oil which has plagued supply out of the region. After the bell the API will report its US energy inventory figures, where analysts look for headline crude stocks to draw by 3.1mln (Cushing expected to draw by 420k); distillates are seen building 0.7mln, and gasoline is seen drawing 1.3mln.

subject: PREVIEW: US TO SELL USD 38BLN 3-YEAR NOTES AT 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
* THIS WEEK's SUPPLY: The US Treasury will auction USD 38bln of new 3-year notes, USD 24bln 10-year re-opening, and USD 16bln 30-year bonds this week. Analysts at UBS says this implied USD 26bln of new cash (ex SOMA-holdings), split between USD 24bln of redemptions, and USD 2bln of coupon payments. Desks have noted that this week's supply will be the first long-end Treasury supply since the June FOMC; the auctions will also be complicated by Fed chair Powell's dual-testimonies to lawmakers (Wed/Thu), with the market looking for signs of whether the Fed is still mulling a July insurance rate cut, now that markets have priced out the prospect of a 'double’ rate cut, consisting of 50bps. The market is, however, still pricing in a 25bps for the July meeting. The 10-year auction will also be interesting after yields on benchmark 10s recently fell below the 2% handle, though have made its way back above the level in Monday. Analysts at BMO will be watching out for domestic investor fund participation at this cycle's auctions; The bank notes that the funds seem undeterred by the continual bullish re-pricings in USTs as June's 3-, 10- and 30-year auctions, which showed the largest share on record allocated to that type of investor. Recent averages imply the 3-year auction will tail 0.2bps, covered 2.52x; the breakdown is seen as 38.00% to dealers, 16.3% to directs, and 45.7% to indirects.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: several Usd/majors test key levels ahead of big midweek line up
content:
USD

The Dollar has pared some gains vs G10 and EM counterparts, but the DXY remains underpinned within a firmer range after extending its post-NFP peak to 97.593 and closer to chart resistance at 97.680 ahead of 97.766. However, Wednesday could provide the next big fundamental driver for the Greenback as Fed chair Powell delivers the first part of his semi-annual testimony and gets the opportunity to respond to the latest jobs data via further guidance for the upcoming July FOMC and the rest of H2 this year. In the interim, Harker (non-voter) told the WSJ that he personally does not see the need to ease right now.

AUD/NZD

Already the worst major following broadly downbeat business and consumer sentiment surveys overnight, the Aussie has extended losses vs its US and Antipodean peers through 0.6940 (Fib support) to around 0.6920 and sub 1.0500 to 1.0480 at one stage, while the Kiwi clings to 0.6600 against the Buck.

GBP/EUR

The Pound has clawed back some losses from near ytd or flash crash lows vs the Dollar and 0.9000 against the Euro as the threat of a cliff edge or disorderly Brexit continues to weigh on Sterling sentiment, while a motion by Grieve to prevent any suspension of Parliament between September 4 and December 18 that could facilitate no deal at all was rejected by HoC speaker and merely added to the uncertainty. However, Cable has reclaimed 1.2450 status, albeit just and Eur/Gbp is back down from the big figure, as Eur/Usd continues to hover around 1.1200 after the single currency ducked under the psychological level, but held above several chart supports with the aid of hefty bids in front of 1.1190 (some 750 mn touted).

CAD 

An air of caution has kept the Loonie on the back foot and mostly under 1.3100 against its US rival, ignoring mixed Canadian housing data and oil price fluctuations as attention was trained on Wednesday’s BoC policy meeting where rates are widely seen unchanged, but guidance could be tweaked. Usd/Cad remains elevated within a 1.3088-3139 range even though Canada escaped fresh tariffs on fabricated steel exports to the US.

JPY

The Yen got to within a whisker of 109.00 lows vs the Usd and probed support at a Fib retracement level (108.92) before rebounding towards 108.70 peaks, as the safe-haven saw renewed safe-haven demand on strained geopolitical factors (like China’s opposition to US arms sales to Taiwan).

TRY

The Lira was licking some wounds after losses made in wake of CBRT intervention by Turkish President Erdogan, but came under renewed pressure amidst reports that the EU is mulling sanctions in the form of pulling EIB aid and possibly shelving talks about aviation before settling down again. Usd/Try currently around 5.7200 between 5.7450-5.6885 trading parameters.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 9th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

9th July 2019

Of note for drug makers Merck & Co (MRK), Eli Lilly (LLY) and Amgen (AMGN): A federal judge struck down a proposed law that would have forced pharma companies to include the wholesale prices of their drugs in television advertising, opting to side with Merck & Co, Eli Lilly and Amgen who had brought a lawsuit in opposition to the bill.

Of note for healthcare names: a federal appeals court panel will hear arguments on Tuesday on whether or not a Texan federal judge was correct in striking down the Affordable Care Act. The judge had ruled the ACA’s requirement for individuals to purchase health insurance is unconstitutional.

DOW

  • 3M Company (MMM) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) has been downgraded to Sector Perform from Outperform at RBC Capital and lowered its PT for the firm to USD 176 from USD 207; analyst Dray believes pressure on the co.’s share price from macro pressures and litigation will persist whilst after an "unsettling string" of guidance cuts, 3M's reputation as a "defensive, high-quality industrial is eroding.” Dray argued that PFAS litigation is an "unquantifiable risk" that is likely to worsen before adding that there is also a risk of more guidance cuts.
  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) – Evercore ISI sees upside in services revenue as being likely in Q2 earnings, driven by acceleration in China centric markets. Evercore estimates App Store developer revenue to grow to roughly USD 9bln, an 18% increase Y/Y. Morgan Stanley corroborated this view. Elsewhere, Apple announced new MacBook Air models, lowering the base price to USD 1,099 (USD 999 for students).
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) and Airbus (EADSY, AIR FP) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) are reportedly mulling withdrawing from the bidding process to supply the Canadian armed forces with new fighter planes, saying the contest is unfairly tilted toward rival defence contractor Lockheed Martin Corp. (LMT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense), maker of the F-35 fighter jet.
  • Home Depot (HD) (Consumer Discretionary/Home Improvement Retail) is facing potential backlash from anti-Trump customers, who started a hashtag #boycotthomedepot after Home Depot co-founder Bernie Marcus expressed his intentions to support Trump in the 2020 elections.
  • Merck & Co. (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) – The FDA has accepted the drug maker’s supplemental biologics license application for the Keytruda six-week dosing schedule, which treats Melanoma and other cancer types.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services), Amazon (AMZN) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – YouTube will relaunch on Amazon’s Fire TV products, and Prime TV will be available for Google’s Chromecast and Android TV, following YouTube pulling from Fire TV in 2017 due to Amazon not selling some Google products, CNBC reports.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) CEO Zuckerberg's personal security chief Liam Booth is to quit after being accused of serious misconduct, including sexual harassment and racism. Elsewhere, Instagram announced a feature to protect accounts from 'unwanted interactions'.
  • Netflix Inc. (NFLX) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) – Cowen analyst Blackledge maintained an Outperform rating and USD 455 PT for the co. ahead of Q2 earnings on 17 July. Blackledge said he expects "solid" results, with original programming hours up by 52% Y/Y whilst also citing recent US survey data which suggested that about 51% of Netflix users will watch "Stranger Things" Season 3 and a possible increase in the number of resubscriptions.
  • PepsiCo Inc. (PEP) (Consumer Staples/Soft Drinks) (USD) reported Q2 EPS 1.54 (exp. 1.50), revenue 16.50bln (exp. 16.42bln), backs FY19 revenue growth guidance of 4%. CEO Laguarta said, "while adverse foreign exchange translation negatively impacted our reported net revenue performance, our organic revenue growth was 4.5% in the quarter."
  • Qualcomm Inc. (QCOM) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) asked a US appeals court to pause a recent antitrust ruling, in which it was ruled that Qualcomm had engaged in anticompetitive patent-licensing practices to keep a monopoly on the mobile chip market.

S&P 500

  • Cardinal Health Inc.’s (CAH) (Health Care/Health Care Distributors) decision to have CEO Kaufmann take on the interim CFO role, following the departure of the co.’s current CFO, indicates a lack of potential successors, argued the WSJ.
  • Kohl's Corp. (KSS) (Consumer Discretionary/General Merchandise Stores) is now accepting Amazon at more than 1,100 stores nationwide, after the two companies
  • Marriott (MAR) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure), Hilton (HLT) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) – JPMorgan analyst Joseph Greff has downgraded both MAR and HLT to Neutral from Overweight, in addition to Ryman Hospitality (RHP) and CorePoint Lodging (CPLG) to Underweight from Neutral. Greff cites himself as becoming “increasingly cautious” on valuations in the Lodging industry, adding that peak valuations, the long cycle, and faltering industry trends indicate “diminished upside”.
  • Mastercard Inc. (MA) (Information Technology/IT Services) has announced the completion of its acquisition of Transfast, after originally announcing intent to purchase the firm on 8 March.
  • Williams Cos. (WMB) (Energy/Oil & Gas Storage & Transportation) is to consolidate its operating areas by reorganising them into regulated and non-regulated areas. The structure will be effective as of 1 Jan 2020.

OTHER

  • Airbus (EADSY, AIR FP) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) is to request that airlines operating its older A380 planes inspect the wings of the aircraft for possible cracks, after some fissures were found on planes in service.
  • Alta Mesa (AMR) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) Chief Accounting Officer Smith is to leave the company, according to the WSJ.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 9th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices are subdued [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.5%] as a profit warning from BASF weighs heavily on the Dax (-1.1%)
  • China’s Vice Foreign Minister Le Yucheng warned of ‘disastrous consequences’ if the US treats China as an enemy
  • US is set to impose duties on fabricated structural steel imports from China and Mexico but will not impose duties on structural steel from Canada; Mexico state this should not impact the USMCA ratification
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US JOLTS, EIA Short Term Energy Outlook, UK Conservative Party Leaders Debate, Fed’s Powell, Bullard, Bostic & Quarles and ECB’s Lane, US 3yr Auction

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were negative following the losses on Wall St where the majors suffered in a continued fallout from the tempered Fed rate cut expectations and cautiousness ahead of Fed Chair Powell's testimony. ASX 200 (-0.1%) was once again led lower by gold miners and with financials pressured after APRA announced it will require Australia's major banks to increase total capital by 3ppts of risk-weighted assets by beginning of 2024 which despite being more generous on the timeline than the initial proposal, is estimated to total an extra AUD 50bln of funds to be put aside by the banks. Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) initially bucked the trend as recent favourable currency moves kept the index afloat for most the session although eventually succumbed to the pressure in late trade. Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were lacklustre amid continued PBoC liquidity inaction and after less than constructive comments from China’s Vice Foreign Minister who warned of disastrous consequences if the US treats China as an enemy, while Geely Auto underperformed in Hong Kong after June sales volume slipped 29% Y/Y which prompted the automaker to cut its FY sales volume forecast by 10%. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with demand subdued as Japanese stocks remained afloat for most the session and amid mixed results at the 5yr JGB auction.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8853 (Prev. 6.8881) 

China’s Vice Foreign Minister Le Yucheng warned of ‘disastrous consequences’ if the US treats China as an enemy and criticized Washington over reports some Chinese-American scientists were treated unfairly in the US. (SCMP)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam acknowledged that the controversial Extradition Bill is ‘dead’ but once again stopped short of withdrawing the bill. (Newswires)

Japan and South Korea are reportedly planning to discuss exports as early as this week. However, there were also comments from Japanese Trade Minister Seko that Japan is not thinking of withdrawing export restrictions on South Korea, while he suggested that whether Japan takes additional export restrictions depends on South Korea's response and that restrictions could either be strengthened or eased. (Newswires)

US

US is set to impose duties on fabricated structural steel imports from China and Mexico but will not impose duties on structural steel from Canada. Mexico later said that US countervailing duties on structured steel from Mexico has nothing to do with Section 232 tariffs or President Trump, while Mexico’s Deputy Foreign Minister said the preliminary subsidy determination announced by the US does not put USMCA ratification in danger and that tariffs are against private companies not the wider steel industry, but added that tariffs are a new problem and Mexico will have to be very active in supporting its steelmakers. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Minister strongly opposes US arms sales to Taiwan, and call on the US to withdraw these arm sales to Taiwan. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond told PM May he will fund her legacy spending plans if she allows Tory MPs free votes on efforts to stop a no-deal Brexit. (Times)

ComRes poll suggested that UK PM candidate Boris Johnson would win 345 seats in Parliament or a 40-seat majority if a general election was held with him as PM, while Labour would receive 207 seats. (Telegraph)

Whitehall sources suggested that if Boris Johnson becomes the next PM, he cannot wait until the summit in October and must start talks with EU quickly in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit and to secure a new deal he claims to want, while the sources added that preparations for a no-deal will also need to be ramped up. (Guardian)

UK opposition Labour Party is set to declare it will campaign for remain in a second referendum on any deal put to parliament by a Tory PM after union bosses agreed to support a change of policy. However, Labour are not committed to being pro-remain in all scenarios and if the Labour party won a General Election before the UK left the EU then they should seek to deliver a Brexit deal. (The Guardian)

UK BRC Sales Like-For-Like (Jun) Y/Y -1.6% vs. Exp. -1.1% (Prev. -3.0%); BRC said 12-month average total sales rose 0.6% which was the slowest pace since record began in 1995. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are in the red this morning, [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.7%] losses are largely led by the Dax (-1.3%) as BASF (-6.0%) and Deutsche Bank (-4.5%) weigh on the index due to a profit warning and in continuation from yesterday’s restructuring downside respectively. BASF are firmly in the red after the issuance of a profit warning where notably the Co. now expect Q2 EBIT before special items to print at EUR 1.0bln, which is 47% down on the prior readin; additionally, Co. have lowered their FY outlook and are planning approximately 6k job cuts by the end of 2021. BASF’s downside has led to the Stoxx Chemical sector (-2.1%) underperforming its peers as the Co. hold a 13.4% weighting in the index. Additionally, the likes of Lanxess (-4.0%), Evonik (-3.0%) and Covestro (-6.0%) are suffering in sympathy. Separately, Danske Bank (-4.0%) also issued a profit warning, where the Co. revised their FY19 outlook down and believe that the generally weak momentum is set to continue. At the other end of the Stoxx 600 are Ocado (+5.6%) as the Co. reported H1 revenue of GBP 874mln which is 10.5% above the prior, aiding the FTSE 100 (-0.2%) in outperforming its peers, albeit still in negative territory, with the bourse also receiving some respite from a softer Sterling this morning.

FX

AUD - The biggest, but not the only G10 loser by any means as the Usd extends its post-NFP gains across the board and the DXY breaches 97.500 to trade at fresh multi-week highs of 97.588. However, the Aussie has been hit independently by a deterioration in NAB business and ANZ consumer confidence that together overshadowed an uptick in the former’s gauge of conditions. Aud/Usd has fallen through 0.6950 and Aud/Jpy is down through the 200 HMA (75.64), while the Aud/NZD cross is breaking below 1.0500 again or testing bids/support at the psychological level even though the Kiwi is also retreating further vs its US counterpart and only just holding above 0.6600.

GBP - No deal Brexit risk and the prospect if not distinct probability of more bleak UK data on Wednesday have piled further pressure on the Pound as Cable slides to a fresh 6 month low and through the 1.2481 base posted last Friday. 1.2450 may offer Sterling some reprieve, though in truth there is little in terms of technical levels until 2019 troughs seen in early January around 1.2435-39 ahead of big option barrier defences lying at 1.2400.

CAD - The Loonie has declined through 1.3100 ahead of Canadian housing data and tomorrow’s BoC policy meeting, with little support derived from firm crude prices or the fact that Canada has been excluded from US tariffs on fabricated structural steel imposed on China and Mexico.

EUR/JPY - Also weaker vs the Dollar as the single currency dips through 1.1200 and nearer short term support around 1.1180-70, while the Yen retreats closer to 109.00 and tests a major Fib just ahead of the big figure at 108.92 (38.2% retracement of the move from 112.40 to 106.78).

EM - Broad weakness vs the Buck, but the Lira is outperforming or holding up better than regional peers in wake of its more pronounced declines on Monday due to CBRT personnel changes and investor angst over the loss of independence/credibility. Usd/Try sitting tight within a 5.7450-7230 range in contrast to Usd/Zar up above 14.2300 and Usd/Rub over 63.8800.

FIXED INCOME 

Core bonds have pulled back further amidst big block trades in US Treasury futures and options centred on 10 year notes and all seemingly targeting or hedging for more downside price movement. As a result, the benchmark has probed just below last Friday’s post-NFP low, while Bunds hit 173.10 and Gilts 131.57 before finding their feet. It is still too early to call an end to the overall bull run, but buyers are clearly wary about stepping back up to the plate given the headline BLS beat and prospect that Fed chair Powell may not commit to July easing or cave to growing outside pressure to signal a concerted rate cutting cycle alongside an end to QT. Note also, it is conceivable that a building supply pipeline warrants concession even though demand for issuance appears strong, and especially via syndication. 

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures have been choppy this morning, with initial weakness seen in-line with this morning profit warning driven poor stock performance. However, the complex is now in positive territory and towards the top end of the day’s range following industry sources state that Russia’s July 1st-8th oil output fell by 3%; which provided a bullish catalyst for oil on an day of relatively light newsflow for the complex thus far. Looking ahead, we have the weekly API release are expectations are for a headline draw of around 2.5mln; in addition, the EIA release their Short Term Energy Outlook which this month contains their Expanded Forecast Discussion at 17:00 BST, with the API and OPEC reports to follow later on in the week.

Gold (-0.7%) is subdued as the yellow metal failed to hold onto the USD 1400/oz mark overnight, and is now towards the session low of USD 1388/oz as the dollar continues to strengthen and extend on its post-NFP gains. Separately, Copper prices are moving towards their lowest level in around 3 weeks on the risk-averse tone and ahead of the week’s key risk events of Powell’s dual testimony.

CME raised NatGas Henry Hub August 2019 maintenance margins by 10% USD 1650 from USD 1500 per contract. (Newswires)

Russian oil output -3% for July 1st-8th vs. June average, falling to 10.79mln BPD vs. Prev. 11.15mln BPD; Rosneft's oil output for the same period is -11%., according to industry sources

- Oil output from Russia's Rosneft has fallen due to oil production at the Yuganskneftegaz unit being 30% lower during July 1st - 8th vs. June average; additionally, Transneft are to limit oil intake from Rosneft., according to sources

subject: Air France (AF FP) - France are to introduce an eco tax on airlines flying out of France, expect approximately EUR 180mln to be raised from 2020., according to a minister
reaction_details: In reaction to this Co. shares moved lower from EUR 8.70 to EUR 8.53

content: Gilts are retreating in line with core counterparts, though in keeping with the pattern of trade yesterday when UK bonds were at the forefront of recovery rallies from post-US payrolls lows they are holding up somewhat better on the way back down, and the Short Sterling strip is also displaying a degree of resilience. Indeed, the 10 year debt future met underlying bids ¼ point below the previous 131.87 settlement vs Bunds that extended their reversal to 173.11 for a 40 tick decline on the day, while 3 month contracts are straddling parity within a -1.5 to +1 tick range ahead of Wednesday’s UK data deluge and a late speech from BoE’s Tenreyro.

Bunds: on the defensive after tame rebound from opening/early lows
content: The 10 year German benchmark looks rather bereft of fresh impetus and direction after Monday’s recovery rally stalled around pre-NFP levels. The US jobs data has changed market perceptions ahead of keynote testimonies from Fed chair Powell and interrupted an almost relentless rally in global bonds on the back of a wave of dovish global Central Bank policy expectations. However, the overall bull trend remains intact amidst ongoing trade and geopolitical risk/uncertainty, so the current bout of consolidation may not last long or manifest as a more meaningful correction. Nevertheless, Bunds just slipped to a marginal new Eurex base at 173.30 from 173.46 at one stage and yesterday’s 173.51 close ahead of a few ECB speakers and Italian retail sales data.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

9th July 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were negative following the losses on Wall St where the majors suffered in a continued fallout from the tempered Fed rate cut expectations and cautiousness ahead of Fed Chair Powell's testimony. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was once again led lower by gold miners and with financials pressured after APRA announced it will require Australia's major banks to increase total capital by 3ppts of risk-weighted assets by beginning of 2024 which despite being more generous on the timeline than the initial proposal, is estimated to total an extra AUD 50bln of funds to be put aside by the banks. Nikkei 225 (Unch.) initially bucked the trend as recent favourable currency moves kept the index afloat for most the session although eventually succumbed to the pressure in late trade. Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) were lacklustre amid continued PBoC liquidity inaction and after less than constructive comments from China’s Vice Foreign Minister who warned of disastrous consequences if the US treats China as an enemy, while Geely Auto underperformed in Hong Kong after June sales volume slipped 29% Y/Y which prompted the automaker to cut its FY sales volume forecast by 10%.

FTSE 100

Tobacco Names - UK PM May’s health paper will propose a tax on the tobacco industry. (Newswires)

Antofagasta (ANTO LN) – Co. reportedly signed H1 2020 copper concentrate supply deals with Chinese copper producers. (Newswires)

WPP (WPP LN) – Co. is thought to be close to an agreement to sell 60% of Kantar to Bain Capital. (Newswires)

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) – Sarasin & Partners have sold over 20% of their stake in the Co. with the remainder of their stake under review; as they believe the Co. are failing to meet the goals under the Paris Climate agreement. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Cineworld (CINE LN) – RBC report suggested that arguments which supported Merlin Entertainments recently going private are equally pertinent for Cineworld. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ANTOFAGASTA (ANTO LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OUTPERFORM AT MACQUARIE

JUST EAT (JE/ LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT BERENBERG

DAX

BASF (BASF GY) – Q2 sales EUR 15.2bln vs. Prev. EUR 15.8bln. Q2 EBIT before special items Exp. EUR 1.0bln, -47%; considerably lower than the Co’s original expectations, net income Exp. EUR 6.5bln, EBIT Exp. EUR 0.7bln, -71%; Q2 results expected to be impacted by a downturn in the auto market and US agricultural sector. Co. have lowered their FY19 outlook: EBIT before special items expected up to 30% lower than Prev., predominantly due to lower earnings in materials, chemicals and agricultural solutions. Co. are planning around 6k job reductions by the end of 2021. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

TLG Immobilien (TLG GY) – Value of the Co’s real estate portfolio has increased to EUR 4.6bln vs. Prev. EUR 4.1bln. (Newswires)

MorphoSys (MOR GY) – Co. and Vivoryon therapeutics have entered an agreement regarding small molecule inhibitors in immune-oncology. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 9th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were negative following the losses on Wall St where the majors suffered in a continued fallout from the tempered Fed rate cut expectations
  • UK Chancellor Hammond told PM May he will fund her legacy spending plans if she allows Tory MPs free votes on efforts to stop a no-deal Brexit
  • UK opposition Labour Party is set to declare it will campaign for remain in a second referendum on any deal put to parliament by a Tory PM
  • US is set to impose duties on fabricated structural steel imports from China and Mexico but will not impose duties on structural steel from Canada
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US NFIB Business Optimism & JOLTS, EIA Short Term Energy Outlook, UK Conservative Party Leaders Debate, Fed’s Powell, Bullard, Bostic & Quarles, US 3yr Auction

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were negative following the losses on Wall St where the majors suffered in a continued fallout from the tempered Fed rate cut expectations and cautiousness ahead of Fed Chair Powell's testimony. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was once again led lower by gold miners and with financials pressured after APRA announced it will require Australia's major banks to increase total capital by 3ppts of risk-weighted assets by beginning of 2024 which despite being more generous on the timeline than the initial proposal, is estimated to total an extra AUD 50bln of funds to be put aside by the banks. Nikkei 225 (Unch.) initially bucked the trend as recent favourable currency moves kept the index afloat for most the session although eventually succumbed to the pressure in late trade. Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) were lacklustre amid continued PBoC liquidity inaction and after less than constructive comments from China’s Vice Foreign Minister who warned of disastrous consequences if the US treats China as an enemy, while Geely Auto underperformed in Hong Kong after June sales volume slipped 29% Y/Y which prompted the automaker to cut its FY sales volume forecast by 10%. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with demand subdued as Japanese stocks remained afloat for most the session and amid mixed results at the 5yr JGB auction.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8853 (Prev. 6.8881) 

China’s Vice Foreign Minister Le Yucheng warned of ‘disastrous consequences’ if the US treats China as an enemy and criticized Washington over reports some Chinese-American scientists were treated unfairly in the US. (SCMP)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam acknowledged that the controversial Extradition Bill is ‘dead’ but once again stopped short of withdrawing the bill. (Newswires)

Japan and South Korea are reportedly planning to discuss exports as early as this week. However, there were also comments from Japanese Trade Minister Seko that Japan is not thinking of withdrawing export restrictions on South Korea, while he suggested that whether Japan takes additional export restrictions depends on South Korea's response and that restrictions could either be strengthened or eased. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond told PM May he will fund her legacy spending plans if she allows Tory MPs free votes on efforts to stop a no-deal Brexit. (Times)

ComRes poll suggested that UK PM candidate Boris Johnson would win 345 seats in Parliament or a 40-seat majority if a general election was held with him as PM, while Labour would receive 207 seats. (Telegraph)

Whitehall sources suggested that if Boris Johnson becomes the next PM, he cannot wait until the summit in October and must start talks with EU quickly in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit and to secure a new deal he claims to want, while the sources added that preparations for a no-deal will also need to be ramped up. (Guardian)

UK opposition Labour Party is set to declare it will campaign for remain in a second referendum on any deal put to parliament by a Tory PM after union bosses agreed to support a change of policy. However, Labour are not committed to being pro-remain in all scenarios and if the Labour party won a General Election before the UK left the EU then they should seek to deliver a Brexit deal. (The Guardian)

UK BRC Sales Like-For-Like (Jun) Y/Y -1.6% vs. Exp. -1.1% (Prev. -3.0%); BRC said 12-month average total sales rose 0.6% which was the slowest pace since record began in 1995. (Newswires)

FX

 

DXY was little changed near the prior day’s highs as most major currencies remained in a holding pattern due to the lack of key data releases and as participants await Fed Chair Powell’s testimony for clues on Fed policy as despite markets pricing in a 97.5% chance of a 25bps rate cut, some were not so convinced including Citi which suggested that a rate cut this month is still not a done deal. EUR/USD and GBP/USD were uneventful and consolidated around the lower end of the 1.1200 and 1.2500 handles respectively while in terms of the latest pertinent headlines, UK Chancellor Hammond has agreed to fund PM May’s legacy spending plans if she allows Tory MPs free votes on efforts to stop a no-deal Brexit, and a fresh ComRes poll also suggested that the Tories could win a 40-seat majority in an election with Boris Johnson at the helm. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was higher as it sustained the recent USD-induced gains and antipodeans were lacklustre with AUD dampened after weak Business Confidence and as AUD/NZD attempted a breakdown of the 1.0500 level.

 

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Jun) 2 (Prev. 7). (Newswires) Australian NAB Business Conditions (Jun) 3 (Prev. 1)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly uneventful overnight in which WTI crude futures proceeded sideways following its recent failure to hold above the USD 58.00/bbl level despite the ongoing Iran-related concerns in which it exceeded agreed enrichment levels and suggested that enrichment of more than 20% was an option. Nonetheless, this failed to provide any sustained support for prices and focus for the energy complex now turns to the latest inventory reports beginning with the APIs later today. Gold also lacked excitement as the steadfast greenback contained the precious metal below the USD 1400/oz level, while copper prices weakened due to the risk averse tone, and failed to benefit from the upside China iron ore futures which surged around 6% shortly after the open on supply concerns and expectations of increased demand.

CME raised NatGas Henry Hub August 2019 maintenance margins by 10% USD 1650 from USD 1500 per contract. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump spoke to French President Macron in regards to ongoing efforts to ensure Iran does not obtain a nuclear weapon, while there were also reports that French President Macron's top diplomatic advisors will be travelling to Iran on Tuesday and Wednesday in an attempt to de-escalate US-Iran tensions. (Newswires)

US

 

The curve flattened, as traders continue to price out the prospects of a 50bps rate cut at the FOMC's July meeting, after the recent payrolls data placed less urgency on the central bank to fire an insurance rate cut, while the trade truce reached at the G20 last week also mitigates some of the immediate downside risks facing the US/global economy. At settlement the 2s/30s flattened the pronounced by 3.8bps, with the 2-year yield rising just under 1.5bps and the 30-year falling by just under 2.5bps. It is worth noting that markets still expect an insurance cut at the July meeting, where the implied probability of a July cut is around 97% on Monday; desks have been increasingly noting that the Fed has historically rarely disappointed when market expectations have been so aggressive. That is in spite of the economy ticking along nicely. Deutsche Bank's analysts said the strength of the NFP data calls into question whether the Fed should be cutting three times this year at all – the market is currently pricing around 67bps. It is hoped now that Fed Chair Powell will reveal some of the Fed's thinking at his dual testimonies this week (Wed/Thu). US T-note futures (U9) settled 1 tick higher at 127-16.

US is set to impose duties on fabricated structural steel imports from China and Mexico but will not impose duties on structural steel from Canada. Mexico later said that US countervailing duties on structured steel from Mexico has nothing to do with Section 232 tariffs or President Trump, while Mexico’s Deputy Foreign Minister said the preliminary subsidy determination announced by the US does not put USMCA ratification in danger and that tariffs are against private companies not the wider steel industry, but added that tariffs are a new problem and Mexico will have to be very active in supporting its steelmakers. (Newswires)

US President Trump said the US will no longer deal with the UK ambassador to the US, while he also reiterated criticism of the way UK PM May dealt with Brexit and looks forward to a new PM. (Twitter)
